title: Ballarat construction boom : big projects to be delivered by 2026 | The Advocate - Hepburn
body_text:
Development in Ballarat shows little sign of slowing, with a slew of major construction projects either scheduled for completion during 2026 or set to change the city skyline throughout the year.

From health care to sport, retail, housing for people and pets, or business expansion, the city continues to evolve as the population grows.
Ballarat Major Events Precinct
The roof is almost on at the first of two new grandstands at Mars Stadium while works are well under way for the adjoining athletics centre, all part of the Ballarat Major Events Precinct.
The precinct encompasses Mars Stadium, the athletics track, and nearby Selkirk Stadium.
The concrete form of the new Mars Stadium grandstands along Creswick Road have been taking shape throughout the year, with the roof of the first grandstand being installed in recent weeks.
The redevelopment of the precinct will add 5000 new permanent seats at the stadium, additional features at Selkirk Stadium and construction of the new athletics track and pavilion on the former Ballarat Showgrounds site.
The new Ballarat Regional Athletics Centre will feature an athletics track, pavilion, light towers and landscaping
The stadium will also be equipped with a new larger videoboard, new standing room embankment, and extra change rooms.
The precinct upgrade also includes fresh facilities at Frank Bourke Oval, with a multimillion dollar upgrade to the pavilion and rooms at the northern oval number two.
The upgrades will include a bigger multipurpose room, four change rooms, internal and external toilets, a kitchen, kiosk and undercover area - a huge benefit to users including North Ballarat Football and Netball Club, the North Ballarat Cricket Club, and the Greater Western Victoria Rebels.
Works on the precinct are due to be completed in September, 2026, which means the Western Bulldogs games scheduled in Ballarat next year have been shifted to 2027.
But the stadium will host three AFL pre-season games in February as part of the 2026 AAMI AFL Community Series - Melbourne v Richmond on February 27, St Kilda v Essendon on February 28, and North Melbourne v Collingwood on March 1.
Ballarat Animal Shelter
Construction of Ballarat's new animal shelter is not expected to get under way until the third quarter of 2026 - more than four years after the state government promised $11.5 million for the new regional facility.
Council will also put in $3 million to the project, which will be built on council-owned land in Yarramie Court, Mitchell Park.
The facility, which will ease the pressure on existing facilities and improve the standard of animal care in the Western Victoria region, aims to serve the needs of the growing community in and around Ballarat.
It will have boarding capacity, separate areas for dogs and cats, more outdoor space for animals and two entrances, one for surrender and one for adoptions.
A Ballarat Council spokesperson said it was expected construction would take 12 to 18 months.
Delacombe Town Centre stage three
Walls are going up as stage three of Delacombe Town Centre, the final stage of the shopping complex precinct, takes shape.
Once complete it will house Coles, Aldi and about 13 specialty shops.
Construction began during April on the new section and the first concrete walls went up in late September. It is estimated the build will take about 12 months.
The new site, known as Delacombe Village, sits south of the current shopping complex, on the other side of Valiant Road behind the first stage of shops, which opened in September 2017.
Developers Troon Group will also build a new 98-place childcare centre within the village, which is currently being offered for lease.
Delacombe Saleyards
Remediation works have begun at Delacombe's historic former saleyards but the future of the site is still unclear.
After sitting empty since the saleyards moved to a newly-built site at Miners Rest in 2018, works began in November to remove contaminated soil and building materials to make the ground safe to build on.
In August 2024, the state government committed to remediate the site and develop it into a jobs and housing precinct.
Council will soon begin community consultation on the future of the 13.6 hectare area, with a draft Precinct Structure Plan (PSP) expected to be released in 2027.
Ballarat Base Hospital redevelopment
Four large tower cranes now dominate the western end of the city skyline as works on the seven-storey clinical services tower power along at Ballarat Base Hospital.
Three cranes are named after volunteers and staff at the hospital - Josie Ashmore, Associate Professor Wasek Faisal and brothers Ashton Kline and Grant Monks - while the fourth displays a large 'thank you' to recognise the patience and understanding of hospital staff, patients, the community and construction workers.
During 2026 the clinical services tower will rise from the site, with the final basement slabs on the ground already poured and the vertical concrete structure begun.
Once complete in 2027, the new hospital tower will feature a new main entrance off Sturt Street, a new emergency department, 100 extra inpatient and short-stay beds, a new state-of-the-art theatre suite, a new and expanded women and children's hub, a new and expanded critical care floor and a helipad on the roof.
The $655 million redevelopment has already seen construction of a new Central Energy Plant and Support Services building completed, and an extension of the car park to provide double the number of spaces.
YPARC
Construction of the $10 million Youth Prevention and Recovery Care Centre for mental health in Newington is scheduled for completion in early 2026.
Grampians teens aged 16 to 18 needing inpatient mental healthcare currently need to be admitted to the Royal Children's Hospital. When the 10-bed YPARC opens next year they will be able to stay closer to home and their support networks for treatment.
The first sod was turned, marking the start of construction, in February with the completion date expected in the first half of the year.
The YPARC will cater for people aged 16 to 25.
The YPARC will feature a home-like environment with 10 private bedrooms with ensuites, communal kitchens, dining and living areas, breakout spaces and an outdoor garden.
Ballarat Station
Ballarat Station's controversial new overpass was lifted into place in November, another piece in the $51 million jigsaw of improving accessibility at the historic transport hub.
The overpass, which contains lift access, will connect the station's two platforms and allow people to move around the station more easily, avoiding the need for people with mobility issues to leave the station and cross at the level crossing to move between platforms.
Other works as part of the station upgrade include a new ramp, stairs and lighting improvements for the northern entry to the station near the multi-storey car park.
The project is scheduled for completion in 2026.
George Weston Foods Flour Mill
Rising from the rear of BWEZ, adjacent to the railway line, a seven-storey building is changing the western landscape of Ballarat.
It is the new $132.9m flour mill for food manufacturing company George Weston Foods which replaces its historic existing mill in North Melbourne.
When construction is complete, expected in the first half of 2026, it will undergo a process of machinery installation and preparation for operational readiness.
The facility will create 174 new jobs, including the transfer of 46 jobs from North Melbourne to Ballarat, and bring in grain from northern and central Victoria to supply the company's operations across the state.
Art Gallery of Ballarat upgrades
The doors of the Art Gallery of Ballarat have been closed since March for a $5.5 million project to replace and upgrade the gallery's heating, ventilation and air conditioning (HVAC) system so conditions are optimal to exhibit and store art.
The works are vital to secure the gallery's future, to ensure it can attract exhibitions from around the world and to protect and maintain the gallery's 12,000-piece collection.
Included in the project is an upgrade to the interior walls which will allow artworks to be attached directly to the wall meaning more works can be displayed. Both lifts on site will also be refurbished and the building's switchboard and generator upgraded.
During the gallery's closure, which are expected to be complete during 2026, a separately-funded upgrade of the gallery's skylights to energy-efficient LED panels will also take place.
During the closure, some artworks have been packed away for storage, others on loan to regional and state galleries and the Backspace Gallery has opened at 43 Mair Street.
Social Housing
The first of the 181 new social housing homes at Leawarra Crescent in Delacombe are expected to be completed during 2026 after ground was broken on the project in December, 2025.
The massive rejuvenation project was first announced in 2021 and the original 66 residents of Leawarra Cres and surrounding streets were moved out of their existing homes.
The 1970s homes, many deemed no longer fit for purpose, were demolished to make way for 117 social and 64 affordable homes, mostly townhouses.
The new homes will be a mix of one, two and three-bedroom properties to help best cater to the region's social housing demand.
But the land has sat empty since.
Minister for Housing and Building Harriet Shing, while visiting the site in December, 2025, said the new homes would be completed in stages from 2026 to 2028. Previous residents will be able to move back if they choose.
The Delacombe development comes alongside the delivery of 439 new social and affordable homes across Ballarat and the Central Highlands including 15 homes under construction in Canadian, 30 in Mitchell Park, 24 in Ballarat and a further 34 to be built across the Central Highlands - most of which will be move-in-ready in 2026.
Eastwood Leisure Complex
One of the city's most diverse community facilities will be largely demolished and rebuilt in a $17 million project to provide a modern, purpose-built venue for community groups.
The sprawling Eastwood Leisure Complex in Ballarat Central has evolved over the past 80 years since it began during 1945 as the Ballarat Youth Centre to support young people transitioning to peacetime life after World War II.
Buildings were donated from the Red Cross from a military hospital at Victoria Park that were used by American Marines who passed through there. Over the decades there have been various upgrades and additions and an ever-expanding number of community groups and programs have been based at the site.
The existing complex has been deemed not fit for purpose, with parts of the building not fully accessible and not compliant with current regulations.
When it closed recently, it was hosting 60,000 visits a year, 67 regular user groups and more than 100 organisations and clubs who used the centre.
The new Eastwood Leisure Complex will provide a modern, purpose-built venue for community groups and expected to be complete in early to mid 2027.
Ballarat-Carngham Road Coles complex
Originally planned to open in mid-2025, then early 2026, there has been no movement or construction on the long-awaited shopping complex at the Alluvium estate on Ballarat-Carngham Road in Winter Valley.
Plans for the complex show a Coles supermarket as an anchor tenant with a range of different businesses alongside a pharmacy, petrol station, gym, medical centre and various retail and food and beverage businesses.
The centre will become part of the Alluvium Estate, which is located on the south side of Ballarat-Carngham Road, between Wiltshire Lane and Dyson Drive.
Learmonth Road shopping complex
Construction should be complete by mid-year on Wendouree's newest retail precinct, a large-format retail hub on Learmonth Road.
Artwork from leasing agents CBRE show Nick Scali, Amart and Pillow Talk among the new tenants of the shopping centre, which occupies land at 121A Learmonth Road between the Eureka Home Maker Centre and Caravan Street.
Earthworks began in March for the complex, which will house showrooms and retail outlets from 1000sm to 2700sqm along with 362 car parks.
Tenants are expected to include a mix of furniture, homewares, automotive, haberdashery, leisure, retail and similar retailers.
City Oval Grandstand
Changerooms at the historic City Oval grandstand are being refurbished and upgraded to bring them up to modern standards and cater for female users.
The $2.5 million works will see extensive renovations of the existing change rooms, including replacing the current wooden floor, which is in poor condition and does not meet modern building standards.
To help expand the changerooms, pods will be built at the rear of the existing change rooms and accessed through a connecting link.
The identical rooms, each with a floor area of about 34 square metres, will contain three toilets, basins and three showers. Construction is scheduled for completion mid-way through the 2026 football season.
Works will also be carried out to rectify structural issues to ensure the longevity of the grandstand, which was built in 1898.
The project is the first part of a major renovation of the venue, with a masterplan expected to be finalised and put out for public consultation within months.
